 PERU SECOND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT AND COMPENSATION FUND (FONCODES) PROJECT 1. POVERTY ALLEVIATION IN PERU A. THE ECONOMIC SETTING 1.1 The comprehensive economic reform programs introduced by the Fujimori government in 1990, including the transformation of the country to a market economy and concurrent efforts to subdue terrorism have brought about a remarkable social and economic recovery in Peru. Inflation was reduced from 7600 percent in 1990 to an estimated 10 percent in 1995 and GDP increased by 20 percent between 1990 and 1994. The economic recovery and subsequent increase in public sector resources allocated to the social sectors have contributed to improved living conditions and a reduction of the population living in poverty from 55 percent in 1991 to 49.6 percent in 1994. During the same period, average consumption levels increased by 29 percent in all areas of the country. 1.2 These results are encouraging, however, the economic recovery to date has succeeded only in bringing per capita GDP back to its 1965 level. In 1994, only 17 percent of the economically active population was adequately employed while 74 percent was underemployed and 9 percent was unemployed. Although income distribution has improved during the past two years, it is still worse than the Latin America average. The major economic reforms of the 1990s have laid the framework for sustainable economic growth. These reforms will need to be complemented by investments in social and economic infrastructure which are targeted to the lowest income groups and poorest areas of the country if the benefits of the reforms are to reach all levels of Peruvian society. B. POVERTY AND LIVING CONDITIONS IN PERU 1.3 In 1994, almost half of Peru's population was classified as poor, that is, having an income not sufficient to purchase the equivalent of a food basket which would meet energy and protein requirements and satisfy the need for other basic non-food items. A fifth of the population was classified as extremely poor, unable to purchase even the equivalent of the food basket. Poverty and extreme poverty are not evenly distributed throughout Peru; almost two thirds of the rural population lives in poverty and 40 percent of the rural poor live in extreme poverty. Although only a third of Lima's population is poor and 4 percent are extremely poor, the highest concentration of poor, about 3.2 million people, reside in Lima. The reduction in poverty between 1991 and 1994 did not benefit all of the poor to the same extent. Poverty declined by 10 percent in Lima, by 6 percent in the rest of the urban coast, 12 percent in the urban Sierra and 4 percent in the rural Sierra (See Table 1.1). 1

Many have no electricity (86%), potable water (90%), school, or health facility. The average distance from these settlements to the nearest health services, schools, communications and markets was 7 kilometers in 1994. Roads and other transportation services which would provide a link with markets and other services outside the community are poor to nonexistent. The other services which would help these communities to end their isolation from the rest of Peru and work their way out of poverty such as adult literacy and agricultural extension, do not reach them. The rural Sierra has the largest number of extremely poor, 1.6 million, the highest proportion of poor, 66 percent, and extremely poor, 44 percent. The prospects for moving out of poverty are limited to a few economic endeavors, including livestock farming and production of handicrafts. About 60 percent of the labor force is employed in the agricultural sector, which has experienced positive growth since 1992 although production levels were still below 1986-89 averages for most crops. The productivity of the labor force engaged in agricultural pursuits is poor, and has improved only marginally over the past three decades. 1.5 Peru's poverty is accompanied by some of the worst social indicators in the LAC region; life expectancy, at 66 years, is lower than in the neighboring middle income countries of Ecuador and Colombia and infant and child mortality are higher (see Table 1.2). Only Haiti and Bolivia have a worse record of achievement in terms of raising life expectancy and lowering mortality. Mortality for all age groups is above average for the region and poor sanitary and living conditions have contributed to the spread of preventable diseases such as tuberculosis, cholera, other gastrointestinal and upper respiratory infections and malaria. Although 76 percent of Lima's population has access to piped water and 50 percent to sewerage services at least part of every day, more than 60 percent of the country's schools lack water and sewerage connections, and less than a third of residents of rural areas had piped water as recently as 1994. The effects of the poor sanitary environment are not limited to the poor; Peruvians of all income groups lose an average of two days of work per month because of inactivity precipitated by ill health. While the loss is greater in financial terms for the rich, who earn more money, the poor suffer more when wages are lost because they do not have the protection of regular salaries, sick leave benefits, and 2
 savings to cushion the impact. Per capita incomes are estimated to be 3 percent lower than expected because of work days lost to illness. More alarming is the prevalence of extreme poverty - 30 percent - among children under 10 years of age. The families of these children are, by definition, unable to provide the basket of food needed to meet their nutritional requirements and satisfy the non-food requirements of the family. Food distribution programs, which should reduce some of the food deficit of the poor, are not always targeted to the poor; in some areas, only half the families receiving food aid are defined as poor or extremely poor. About twenty percent of Peruvian children 6 - 17 years of age work, primarily as unpaid family laborers in rural areas. Most live in the Rural Sierra; only 6 percent live in Lima. Although more than 90 percent are theoretically enrolled in school, attendance levels in some areas average only two days per week. The living conditions of the Peruvian poor reflect the uneven distribution of the benefits of development in the past. Expanding small-scale improvements in social and economic infrastructure and targeting them to the poor, especially in rural areas, represent a serious challenge for the Peruvian government. C. GOVERNMENT POVERTY ALLEVIATION STRATEGY 1.7 The Peruvian government is faced with the difficult task of resuming economic growth and reducing poverty on a sustainable basis after years of deterioration. In the decade between 1981 and 1991, the level of government expenditures was cut in half. Between 1987 and 1991, per capita GDP decreased by 25 percent and government spending fell to US$115 per capita, equivalent to 8 percent of GDP. Health and education expenditures declined far below the region's averages and infrastructure, including roads, water and sanitation systems are now in an advanced state of decay. Increasing public expenditure alone will not guarantee better coverage and quality of services. There are four elements which are critical to ensure sustainable improvements in public expenditures and the provision of services: (i) improvements in the efficiency of allocations; (ii) establishment of a well-defined relationship between the central, 3
 regional and local governments; (iii) improvements in the management of human resources; and (iv) strengthening the public sector financial management process.' 1.8 The Fujimori government recognized the need to ameliorate the social costs of the economic adjustment program soon after the program was initiated. Analysis of the determinants of poverty based on the findings of the 1991 Living Standards Measurement Survey indicated that gains in income were positively correlated with investments in human capital, including education, health and nutrition interventions. Social programs to improve human capital needed to be complemented by physical capital accumulation to stimulate economic growth in order to reduce poverty. Nevertheless, the minimum needs of the poorest would not be satisfied in the medium term, even when the most optimistic assumptions related to the growth of the economy were considered. The government's second term commitment to reduce current levels of extreme poverty by 50 percent by the year 2000 will require not only an increase in social expenditures but also the development of mechanisms to stimulate economic growth, promote competitiveness, effort, solidarity, austerity and savings. 1.9 Public social expenditure has increased by a factor of four since 1990, from 21 to 41 percent of total public expenditure and from 3 to 7.5 percent of GDP (See Table 1.3). There are two major elements of the social expenditure program: the Social Expenditure Improvement Program which provides substantial budgetary allocations to those programs of the Ministries of Health, Education and Justice which benefit the poorest segments of the population, and the social emergency funds provided to several autonomous organizations within the Ministry of the Presidency including FONCODES, INFES, PRONAA, CoOPOP2 and others. Emphasis has been placed on programs and interventions that improve the quality of social expenditure so that an optimum trickle-down effect can be obtained and the scarce resources can be used to minimize the social gap between rich and poor. In order to attain its objective of an economic growth rate averaging 5 percent a year, a significant increase in public and private savings will be necessary. Social expenditures will have to be well targeted and efficiently implemented if they are to be successful in delivering social services to the neediest. During the next few years, greater emphasis will be placed on cost-effectiveness in the assignment of resources, better targeting to the most vulnerable groups, closer monitoring of expenditures and results, and functional and financial decentralization of social programs. 1.11 The government has made an effort during the past five years to define the problems associated with inefficient and ineffective spending and is laying the groundwork for basic reforms in health, education, and food and nutrition programs, for which it is receiving considerable support from the international donor community. In the future, the line ministries expect to concentrate their efforts on policy formulation, legislation, the establishment of norms and standards for the provision of public services and transfer responsibility for the provision of many basic services to local governments. Many of these reforms have not been well defined. There are unanswered questions related to the formula to be used for financing and cost recovery, the degree of autonomy and accountability of individual facilities for the services provided, and the role of central, regional and local governments. Until the government has overcome the existing weaknesses in its public sector expenditure system and in the provision of social services, the Ministry of the Presidency will continue to complement the efforts of the line ministries and the regional and local governments. The role of FONCODES in the implementation of demand- 5

D. BANK INVOLVEMENT IN POVERTY ALLEVIATION 1.12 The Bank resumed lending to Peru in 1991 with a strategy designed to support the macroeconomic and structural adjustment programs of the government. By 1993, the Bank's portfolio included loans for Trade Policy Reform, Structural Adjustment, Financial Sector Adjustment, Privatization Technical Assistance, and Privatization Adjustment. In 1993, there was a shift to investment lending intended to support the Government's long-term objectives of growth and poverty reduction through institution building, infrastructure development and poverty alleviation programs. In 1995, the portfolio included loans for the Social Development and Compensation Fund, Electricity Privatization, Lima Water Rehabilitation and Management, Rural Roads, Basic Health and Nutrition, and Primary Education. 1.13 Poverty reduction is the central objective of the Bank's involvement in Peru.3 Projects with FONCODES, in Basic Health and Nutrition, Basic Education, and Rural Roads Rehabilitation combine poverty alleviation with investments in rehabilitation and maintenance of public services which have been neglected and technical assistance in support of privatization and t.he development of the complementary regulatory and legal framework. The Bank's strategy for FY95-97 continues to pursue the long-term objectives of poverty alleviation, infrastructure development and institution building through investment lending in infrastructure and the social sectors. E. T1E SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT AND COMPENSATION FuND (FONCODES) 1.14 In December, 1993, the Bank's Board of Directors approved the first loan to the Peruvian government for the Social Development and Compensation Fund (FONCODES). The loan of US$ 100 million was complemented by parallel financing from the Interamerican Development Bank (US$100 million). A European donor consortium including Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland financed a similar project4 for US$14 million equivalent in the Inka Region. Government financing (US$200 million) and beneficiary contributions (US$42 million) brought the total value of support for FONCODES to US$495 million. The Bank loan was to be implemented over a period of three years, from 1994 to 1996. 1.15 The objectives of the project were to sustain the government's poverty alleviation efforts, mitigate the social costs of macroeconomic adjustment and strengthen the institutional capacities of FONCODES. The project was to support a range of community-based, labor intensive projects, with a strong focus on education, health and nutrition, and other activities that would assist poor rural and peri-urban populations.  investment: social assistance, social infrastructure, economic infrastructure and income and employment generation. In addition to the locally generated small-scale demand driven projects, FONCODES financed a series of centrally planned and executed Special Programs to manufacture shovels for farmers, launches for community transportation in the Selva, school shoes, knapsacks, furniture, and school breakfasts. The Bank declined to finance these projects because they were not consistent with the demand-driven strategy of the Fund. The Bank project also provided support for the institutional development of FONCODES, which was considered essential if the project's other objectives were to be met. At the request of the Bank, FONCODES drafted environmental assessment guidelines acceptable to the Bank, incorporated them in the Operational Manual, and modified the Operational Manual to respond to other Bank concerns related to the definition of the project menu and provision of complementary inputs, including beneficiary contributions to ensure project sustainability. In addition, a Letter of Social Policy was prepared by the government and reviewed and approved by the Bank. The letter was followed by the development of the social sector strategy described in Paragraphs 1.8 - 1.1 1. 1.16 Unlike some other social fund projects, FONCODES was not established with World Bank or other international financing. FONCODES was created in 1991 by the Fujimori government to finance social investment projects prepared by the Fund (the Special Projects mentioned in the previous paragraph) and by local communities in poor areas of the country, to promote temporary employment, channel resources to the poorest areas of the country, and assist in emergency situations. Between 1991 and 1993, the only external support for FONCODES was a 1992 institutional development grant from the Interamerican Bank (IDB). The Fund had already learned a number of important lessons prior to the preparation of the project, including the need for effective targeting, clear definition of the project menu, establishment of objective criteria for project evaluation and approval, regular supervision of project implementation, and establishment of good project administration and financial management procedures. 1.17 The ongoing project has been monitored regularly by Bank project supervision missions, several of which have been carried out jointly with IDB staff. In addition, there have been numerous field visits to FONCODES projects by Bank managers and staff working with other projects in Peru, and three external ex-post evaluations which have examined more than 500 completed projects. Overall, the project has maintained a satisfactory or highly satisfactory rating since its approval. Projects have been well targeted to poor areas, demand-driven and executed locally. The technical quality of project appraisals has been good and largely free from political interference. Significant short term employment has been generated. FONCODES staff continue to improve its operations through an ongoing informal process of review and fine-tuning, implementing recommendations generated by FONCODES personnel in Lima and the 23 regional offices, by Bank missions and through lessons learned from other social funds. 1.18 Ajoint, World Bank-Interamerican Bank Midterm Review of the project and the work of FONCODES was initiated in March, 1995, and concluded in November, 1995, when the findings of the ex-post evaluation of projects were discussed with FONCODES. The Midterm Review consisted of two joint IDB-Bank missions, the third and largest external ex-post evaluation to date of 300 projects completed and an extensive beneficiary assessment, both of which were undertaken by a local consulting firm. The Midterm Review focused on targeting, selection and 7
 prioritization of projects, project execution and supervision, project quality, sustainability and impact. Institutional development issues addressed included the overall management, administration and decentralization of FONCODES, improvement of the MIS, procurement and disbursement arrangements, relations with line ministries and local governments, training, consultant assistance and studies. In addition, the government provided an update on the implementation of the Letter of Social Policy and its overall poverty alleviation strategy. 1.19 Findings of the Midterm Review. Between 1991 and September 1995, FONCODES received more than 45,000 applications for projects and had financed 16,786 projects at a total cost of US$650 million equivalent. The 1994 LSMS revealed that 40 percent of improvements in infrastructure and services in poor rural communities had been financed by FONCODES. During 1994, the World Bank project financed 2,184 FONCODES subprojects with a total value of US$52 million. The average project size was US$25,000. The IDB project had financed 2,015 projects for US$63.8 million equivalent, with an average project size of US$32,000 equivalent. The review team found that FONCODES activities were notable for: (a) their innovativeness with respect to the nontraditional form of intervention in poor communities; (b) the adequacy of the targeting mechanisms, including census data, used to allocate resources, 80 percent of which were allocated to poor or extremely poor districts; (c) the degree of community participation, including women and indigenous groups, and decentralized implementation of projects; (d) the extensive territorial reach of FONCODES which financed projects in areas where the presence of the public sector was precarious to nonexistent; and (e) the management capacity of FONCODES as reflected in the mobilization and use of resources for the financing of projects. 1.20 The technical competence and high degree of motivation of FONCODES personnel at the central and regional offices was also noted. Some of the Lessons Learned from the Midterm Review are summarized below. Lessons learned from Bank involvement in other social funds are summarized in Annex 11. 1.21 Targeting and Prioritization of Projects. Project targeting has been good and is improving; in 1994, 66 percent of projects were targeted to poor and extremely poor departments. By 1995, more than 80 percent were targeted to poor districts. Targeting to the district level facilitates the identification of poor and extremely poor population groups within departments which are classified as not poor but which have significant poor populations such as Lima. The global prioritization and selection of projects by category (social assistance, social infrastructure, economic infrastructure, employment generation) is established by FONCODES in Lima. The need to rethink the process of establishing priorities in Lima rather than at the regional or local level is one of the lessons learned from the successful use of district development committees to determine priorities and coordinate projects in the Cusco and Cajamarca areas and from the implementation of a series of pilot integrated development projects in four other rural areas of the country. 8
 1.22 Project Execution and Sustainability. The satisfactory quality of project execution and supervision has been confirmed in numerous site visits throughout the country and by four ex-post evaluations of over 500 projects. More than 80 percent of projects are judged sustainable, that is, staffed and equipped to operate as planned with arrangements made with the line ministries to cover recurrent costs such as personnel for schools and health posts, supplies and equipment. Operations and maintenance shortcomings are most common in water and sewerage projects, where commitments from local governments to assist in this area are not always backed up by the necessary technical expertise and budgetary resources. In 80 percent of projects in the Selva, 54 percent in the Sierra and 46 percent on the Coast, the community is participating in operations and maintenance efforts. With additional training during project preparation and execution, these numbers could be increased. One area of concern which has surfaced in the preparation of this second project is the actual application of the environmental assessment procedures. 1.23 Institutional Development. The investments in institutional development for a Social Fund which is defined as temporary must be designed to improve its performance and facilitate its work for the relatively brief period of time of its existence. In the case of FONCODES, these investments have been modest and have been well focused on the immediate requirements of the Fund. FONCODES offices have been rehabilitated, the information system is being expanded and improved, communications and computing equipment to support decentralized project management in 23 regional offices have been acquired, primarily with funding from the IDB. Technical assistance and training focused on the use of individual consultants to analyze the LSMS and Census data to develop improved targeting mechanisms and supervise project execution, staff training in the evaluation and supervision of projects, and the contracting of consulting firms to conduct external ex-post evaluations of projects completed. These investments have laid the groundwork for the second project and the continuation of FONCODES activities for another 3 to 5 years. 1.24 Coordination with Line Ministries and Local Governments. Relations of FONCODES with the line ministries and local governments have been uneven, despite continuing efforts to resolve issues at the local, regional and national level. The result has been that about 10 percent of schools and health facilities constructed with FONCODES financing have no staff, equipment and materials, or recurrent budget from the line ministry. In similar cases, extensions of water, drainage and sewerage systems to poor areas have been completed in municipalities which have no financial or material resources to assure operations and maintenance. Written agreements (convenios) have been executed with the municipalities and with the Ministries of Health, Education, Transport, Agriculture, and the other autonomous offices within the Ministry of the Presidency, including INFES, FONAVI and COOPOP. These agreements have not always been accompanied by the appropriate follow-up by FONCODES or the other parties to the agreements. FONCODES has completed a study which examines the coordination between the line ministries, local governments and FONCODES with a view to improving coordination in the future and developing criteria for the gradual transfer of responsibility for social infrastructure and programs currently supported by FONCODES. In addition, FONCODES managers have been meeting with representatives of the line ministries to review and update the agreements which govern their relationships in order to improve coordination in the future and provide for ongoing monitoring and periodic evaluation of the efficacy of the coordination mechanisms. At appraisal, 9
 FONCODES provided the Bank with copies of the new convenios with the line ministries and identified the staff members who would be responsible for following up with each institution (See Para. 3.48-3.49). 1.25 Other Issues. The demand for FONCODES projects has far exceeded the resources of the Fund. This has led to the accumulation of a large backlog of project applications which have not been evaluated. The time between project presentation and evaluation has stretched from 57 to 192 days and the time between approval and the first disbursement of funds has increased from 36 to 55 days. In addition, 2,000 projects remained incomplete. FONCODES had reduced the number of incomplete projects to 425 by November, 1995 and will begin to address the project backlog during 1996. To reduce the project backlog, FONCODES has developed a simplified application form which will allow it to respond rapidly to applications before the community invests significant resources in project development. FONCODES has not worked extensively with NGOs in the past, as few NGOs were working in rural areas when FONCODES was established because of the security situation. A Letter of Social Policy was prepared by the government as a condition for international financing of the first Social Development Fund Project. The social policy strategy includes the design of a Program of Targeted Social Expenditures and a proposal to develop a Plan for Social Stabilization. The Program of Targeted Social Expenditures uses public sector resources generated by economic adjustment and recovery and the proceeds of privatization of public enterprises to target expenditures for basic social services provided by the Ministries of Health, Education and Justice to the programs most likely to reach the lowest income groups and the poorest areas of the country. Public social expenditure for the targeted social programs tripled between 1994 and 1995, from US$88 million to US$263 million (See Table 1.4). Continued expansion of the targeted programs is anticipated. The plan for social stabilization addresses medium-term social policy and planning issues such as the role of the social ministries in the development and monitoring of norms and standards, decentralization of social programs to the local government, and coordination between local governments, the social fund and the line ministries. The Peruvian government has estimated that the cost of shifting its focus from the financing of short-run emergency actions to a medium-term program which meets the basic needs of the population will require additional external financing increasing from US$655 milllion in 1996 to US$970 million in 2000 (See table 1.5). 10

ORIGIN OF THE PROJECT 2.1 The positive results of the first Social Development Fund project financed by the Bank, continuing problems related to unsatisfactory living conditions, especially in rural areas and among the lowest income groups, the inauspicious short term prospects for a significant improvement in the capacity of the line ministries and local governments to respond to the needs of the poor, and the strong demand from Peruvian communities for additional projects financed through FONCODES (see Table 2. 1) provide a strong justification for the development of a second project to support the operations of FONCODES. The Peruvian government has estimated that over the next five years, there will be a substantial increase in the deficit in social expenditures required to ameliorate the living conditions of the poor and to achieve the government's goal to reduce extreme poverty by 50 percent by the year 2000. It will work more closely with the local government entities to develop their capacity to plan, prepare and execute small scale investment projects, mobilize the community in support of these projects, and ensure their sustainability by participating in arrangements for operations, maintenance, and cost recovery. FONCODES projects have been executed in remote areas which the central government has not always been able to serve. The use of FONCODES to test new ideas on a limited scale using project designs adapted to local conditions and to reach remote areas will advance the government agenda to reduce extreme poverty, which is prevalent in widely scattered settlements in which only small projects are appropriate. 2.4 The Bank has made a commitment to support the government's poverty alleviation strategy as part of its effort to ensure the sustainability of the overall economic adjustment program. It is generally acknowledged that Peru has met successfully many of the challenges before it. Stable prices, stronger market mechanisms, and public order have increased productivity and improved the conditions for private investment. However, improving the quality of people's lives and capabilities will require a sustained effort to reduce poverty by building on the lessons of recent years and increasing the endowment of resources including human capital. Targeted investments in education, health, nutrition, economic and social infrastructure and programs will be needed to reach the poorest communities, many of which still lack basic social and economic infrastructure and services. FONCODES has played a prominent role in delivering public services and executing the kind of small scale investments in infrastructure and services in remote areas which have been most difficult for the line ministries and the central government to implement. 2.5 This project will build on the demonstrated capability of FONCODES to target its investments to the poorest areas of the country, to increase capacity for project planning and execution at the local level, and respond to the demands of the community. The ability of FONCODES to work more effectively in the poorest areas of the country and determine priorities within poor communities has been enhanced by the updated poverty map and a 1995 survey of basic needs in more than 18,000 of the country's poorest communities. 13

PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DEscRPTiON 2.6 The project would continue to support the Government's poverty alleviation strategy to target its investments to the poorest areas and population groups in the country. It would contribute to the government's decentralization strategy by building local capacity in project planning, execution, operations and maintenance of small scale infrastructure and public services. It would contribute to the longer term goal of sustained poverty reduction through investments in productive projects designed to stimulate economnic activity in poor communities. It would focus on meeting priority needs for social and economic infrastructure and programs, through projects designed with the participation of poor communities in consultation with local governments and line ministries. The resources for projects would be allocated based on the poverty map and community survey of basic needs developed by FONCODES, both of which disaggregate data to the district or community level. The ability to target projects to this level permits a degree of precision in targeting which was not possible under the first project (See Para. 3.11-3.16). 2.7 The Bank project would finance: (i) a broad menu of small-scale projects in social infrastructure, social assistance, economic infrastructure and productive activities; and (ii) institutional development of FONCODES designed to support further decentralization of project management responsibilities, development of new promotion and project preparation strategies to increase the participation of women and indigenous communities; and evaluation of subproject costs, benefits and impact, and project sustainability. FONCODES would continue to emphasize transparency with respect to the participation of the beneficiaries in project management and supervision, and work more closely with line ministries and local governments to improve coordination and ensure project sustainability. A survey of basic needs in more than 18,000 communities revealed that only 32% had safe water and waste disposal systems, 13% had electricity, and 90% had a primary school. The second FONCODES project is expected to satisfy virtually 100% of the need for primary education infrastructure, about 50% of the need for water and sewerage systems, and approximately 20 % of the need for electricity. If local governments contribute to the satisfaction of these needs either through co-financing with FONCODES or through parallel projects, the basic needs identified by this survey could be satisfied more rapidly. PROJECT COMPONENTS 2.8 The project, with a total cost of US$430 million, would have two components: (i) Community-based subprojects in social infrastructure, social assistance, economic infrastructure and productive activities (US$420.7 million equivalent); and (ii) institutional development (US$7.8 million equivalent). The World Bank and IDB loans would finance the same menu of projects. 2.9 Community-based Subprojects (US$420.7 million). The first component would include two broad categories of community-based subprojects: social infrastructure and social assistance, and economic infrastructure and productive activities. As the need for basic social services is met and the capacity of the line ministries increases, community demand and the composition of FONCODES' portfolio is expected to shift gradually to economic infrastructure 14
 and productive activities. The subprojects would continue to be identified by community groups and executed by the communities, local contractors, and non-governmental organizations in close cooperation with local governments and line ministries. 2.10 Social Infrastructure and Social Assistance. A broad range of subprojects designed to meet basic needs and improve social and living conditions would be financed. There would be a strong focus on primary education, family planning information and education. Water treatment and supply, waste disposal including sewage treatment systems, environmental sanitation, health post rehabilitation and equipment, primary school rehabilitation and equipment are being financed by the ongoing project and will continue under the new project. 2.11 Economic Infrastructure and Productive Projects. The project would provide support for the rehabilitation, extension and construction of wells and small scale irrigation systems, land rehabilitation and reforestation, small bridge, road and sidewalk rehabilitation, marketing infrastructure, secondary electrical supply systems, and productive projects designed to improve the economic potential of poor rural communities. FONCODES expects to build on its past experience with productive projects at first, and test new projects on a pilot basis prior to initiating a large scale commitment to this line of subprojects. 2.12 Two types of productive projects are envisioned: (a) projects which are designed to increase production for autoconsumption in order to improve the nutritional status of extremely poor families; and (b) projects designed to increase production for sale in local markets. Some of the productive projects which have proven successful and sustainable in the past include food storage and distribution centers, small animal production, bee-keeping and production of honey, fish farms, small food processing facilities, and livestock improvement schemes. The poorest areas of the rural Sierra and Selva are expected to be the primary beneficiaries of productive projects. FONCODES is developing criteria for the productive projects, including the type and size of project to be financed, the type of local organization required to plan and implement the projects, beneficiary participation guidelines, economic and financial analysis to be applied, and ex-ante and ex-post evaluation designs. A maximum of US$12.4 million equivalent, about 3 percent of project resources, will be available to finance productive projects (See Positive List, Annex 13), These projects would be targeted to very poor and extremely poor communities. The minimum rate of return required to qualify for FONCODES financing would be 12 percent for type B projects and at least 30 percent of the community members should be expected to benefit from both types of projects. At negotiatons, it was agreed that disbursements for these projects would be limited to US$4.3 million equivalent under the Bank loan (para. 4.1(a)). 2.13 Institutional Development (US$7.8 million). The focus of institutional development is expected to shift gradually to the regional offices, communities, and local governments. This component would finance further decentralization of FONCODES operations, including procurement of some vehicles and equipment for the regional offices; development of the MIS; training of FONCODES staff in the use of the MIS, the new Operations Manuals, participatory techniques designed to increase the involvement of women and indigenous groups in FONCODES projects, simplified project preparation methods, applications of the revised procurement and disbursement procedures, performance indicators, and environmental guidelines; 15
 and training for local governments, NGOs and community leaders in the preparation and operations and maintenance of FONCODES projects, and the participation of women. Consultant assistance would be used for the preparation, supervision, and ex-post evaluation of subprojects, a series of special evaluations of innovative projects including productive projects, staff training, beneficiary assessments, audits of subprojects and financial audits. 2.14 Project Management. FONCODES administrative costs have tended to average about five percent of total operating costs. These expenses are expected to amnount to about US$21.5 million and will be borne by the Peruvian govemment as part of the counterpart financing. The administration of all community-based subprojects is governed by the instructions contained in FONCODES Operations Manuals which provide specific guidelines for project promotion, identification, prioritization, preparation, implementation, completion and liquidation. 2.15 The Operations Manual lays out standard operating procedures for FONCODES staff and a User's Guide explains FONCODES' operations to members of the nucleo ejecutor, other beneficiaries, local governments, and NGOs. Both the Operations Manual and the User's Guide were reviewed and approved by the Bank for the first project. For the second project, FONCODES has agreed to make adjustments to both documents to reflect changes in its operating procedures. FONCODES Operations Manual and User's Guide cover the following general areas: (i) the menu of projects which are eligible for financing by FONCODES which in the future will also include standard project designs to be used in the poorest communities where project preparation capacity is limited, and a positive list of the kinds of productive projects eligible for financing (See Annex 13); (ii) the project cycle, including promotion of FONCODES projects and technical assistance to extremely poor communities; prioritization and selection of projects, both by the communities, as they organize and prepare a project, and by FONCODES staff, who will use the new computerized system recently developed for this purpose; ex-ante project appraisal, including technical, economic, social and environmental criteria; requirements for environmental assessment (see para. 2.34 - 2.41), project execution, procedures to be followed for direct contracting or competitive bidding, accounting, financial management requirements and procedures for disbursements of funds to the nucleo ejecutor, the relationship between FONCODES, the nucleo ejecutor, and the inspector; project monitoring and supervision; project liquidation, project audits, and arrangements for operation and maintenance of projects including cost recovery mechanisms where applicable; (iii) community participation, including the process by which the nucleo ejecutor is elected, requirements for community meetings and recording of the minutes of all meetings; the minimum levels of beneficiary contribution 16

ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT 2.34 The proposed Project is rated environmental category "B". FONCODES subprojects are small in size (in 1994 the average Bank-financed sub-project had a budget of less than US $ 25,000), and are concentrated in activities which are not expected to have an environmental impact (such as the construction and rehabilitation of classrooms). First, staff at the regional offices initially mark project proposals as "A", "B", or "C", according to their likely environmental impact. Requirements then vary according to the category of the subproject: "A" subprojects must satisfy no further environmental criteria; applications for "B" subprojects need to include documentation to demonstrate that the appropriate mitigation measures detailed in the Operations Manual have been taken before the project file is considered complete; "C" subprojects require a full-fledged environmental assessment. Second, FONCODES evaluators must fill out a "field form" during the mandatory visit to the proposed project site. To complete this "field form", evaluators must assess the proposed site, the use of natural resources, and the operation and maintenance of the subproject in question. Subprojects cannot be approved unless problems identified in this "field form" are resolved. Third, prior to final approval, FONCODES staff in Lima or at the regional offices (depending on the size of the subproject and the responsibilities of the regional office in question, as outlined in paras. 3.7 - 3.10 below) review the subproject to assess whether it is conceptually sound. This occurs because proposals that are originally marked "B" or "C" are returned to the nucleo ejecutor until they include documentation to show that environmental concerns have been addressed. At this point, it is considered that the project in question has satisfied environmental requirements, and it is moved into the "A" category; (ii) the lack of an environmental specialist in the central office in Lima; (iii) insufficient training in environmental assessment in the field offices, especially given the high turnover rates of staff; (iv) the absence of effective indicators to monitor environmental procedures; (v) the absence of 24
 environmental criteria from the supervision phase of the FONCODES project cycle; and (vi) the lack of ex-post evaluations of the environmental impact of FONCODES subprojects. 2.37 The project will address these concerns by acting in four broad areas: (i) incorporating a full-time environmental specialist to the staff at the central office in Lima; (ii) building up institutional capacity in Lima and at the regional offices; (iii) regularly evaluating the environmental impact of subprojects; (iv) incorporating an environmental awareness and education component into the promotion and training stages of the FONCODES project cycle. 2.38 Environmental specialist: FONCODES has hired an environmental specialist for the central office in Lima. PROJECT TARGETING 3.11 Since its creation in 1991, FONCODES has worked to design appropriate and transparent criteria to identify and reach the lowest income groups, especially those most in need of basic services. Two basic instruments have been developed for this purpose: (i) a Referential Resources Allocation System (RRAS); and (ii) the ex-ante evaluation of projects submitted to FONCODES. 3.12 FONCODES has generally assigned 60 percent of its resources to rural areas, and has then used the RRAS to pre-allocate resources to smaller geographic units. The RRAS is based on a series of poverty indices and poverty maps weighted by the size of the population in an area. Over the course of the last four years, FONCODES has perfected the RRAS by including a greater number of socio-economic variables to create a more sophisticated index to measure poverty. Using information from the 1993 [X Population and IV Housing Census, provincial-level poverty maps are now based on 11 socio- economic indicators, including illiteracy rates, the number of working children, and the lack of basic services. FONCODES has also used ever-smaller geographic units, and has recently constructed district-level poverty maps by weighting provincial indices with district-level information on the rate of chronic malnutrition. By pre-assigning resources to individual districts, FONCODES is now able to target investments at the level of the smallest political unit in Peru. Within the project cycle, the ex-ante evaluation carried out by FONCODES regional offices includes a socio-economic assessment, and a mandatory field visit to the community which has prepared the project proposal. This further ensures that projects are really targeted at poor communities and respond to their needs. 3.13 A review of the geographical distribution of FONCODES projects indicates that they have been well targeted. This is consistent with earlier findings that the poorest communities do not always have the capacity to identify and prepare projects. There appears to have been relatively little leakage of FONCODES resources to the non-poor, especially since regular and acceptable districts often contain significant pockets of poverty. 31

In addition, most FONCODES subprojects have benefited women because they have provided services or built infrastructure in areas which are often seen as high priority by women, such as education, health, nutrition, sanitation, and community organization. 3.32 The project would provide support to FONCODES to ensure that women continue to participate fully in all stages of the project cycle and benefit from FONCODES subprojects. E. BENEFICIARY CONTRIBUTIONS 3.33 FONCODES has generally paid beneficiaries for most of the unskilled labor required for the execution of subprojects. FONCODES has followed this policy for a number of reasons: (i) its objective is the alleviation of poverty, and the generation of 37
 income, even if transitory, is regarded as an important benefit of the subprojects; (ii) many FONCODES investments, such as the construction of schools and health posts, do not raise the incomes of beneficiaries in the short run; and (iii) FONCODES investments have been targeted at extremely poor, very poor and poor communities, many of which do not earn enough income to satisfy the nutritional requirements of their families, and are therefore ill-suited to donate their labor for free. 3.34 However, FONCODES beneficiaries have generally contributed to the execution of subprojects by providing all of the required land, as well as part of the construction materials, cash, or unskilled labor. Participation came in the form of free labor (89 percent), cash (1 1 percent), or materials (8 percent). Fully 97 percent of beneficiaries stated that they "would be willing to contribute to the execution of another FONCODES project", 89 percent of them with free labor, 10 percent with cash, and 9 percent with materials. 3.35 FONCODES has recently developed a uniform system to establish the rninimum levels of beneficiary contribution mandated for the execution of subprojects. In order to increase the sustainability of subprojects, beneficiaries would be required to contribute 10 percent of the total amount of unskilled labor required for execution of the subproject, for all poverty levels and all project types. Voluntary contributions of land, labor, cash, and materials by the beneficiaries above this required 10 percent would continue to be will continue to be accepted and included in project accounting. Duplication of efforts has been avoided by an interagency agreement in which geographic areas of work are defined and agreed upon. PRONAMACHCS does not pay beneficiaries in cash, and it requires that beneficiaries contribute all of the unskilled labor needed for the execution of the subprojects in exchange for a combination of food, seeds, and tools. F. SELECTION AND PRIORITIZATION OF SUBPROJECTS 3.37 FONCODES' demand-driven strategy, which allows communities to select and execute their own projects, is an important step to ensure the sustainability of investments. 38

Because they rely on such grass-roots democratic processes, FONCODES projects tend to meet a priority need of the community: the Midterm Review indicated that 64 percent of beneficiaries participated in the community assembly at which the project was selected, that there was a majority agreement at 98 percent of these assemblies, and that the project executed by FONCODES was regarded as "that which was most needed by the community" by 90 percent of the beneficiaries. FONCODES projects promote community mobilization and organization, and thus help to strengthen the fabric of civil society. 3.38 FONCODES continues to search for the best way to combine grass-roots participation with a more structured approach to local development, and is currently reviewing three pilot projects financed by PREDES, PRIDER, and the mesas de concertaci6n in Cajamarca8 which have brought communities and local authorities together on a regular basis in an effort to prioritize and coordinate the selection and execution of development projects. One promising approach would attempt to "articulate" subprojects. Once this project had been executed, communities would be encouraged to consult with local officials and NGOs, and prepare proposals for additional, complementary projects. G. CONTRACTING, PROJECT EXECUTION AND SUPERVISION 3.41 When a community-based project is approved, FONCODES signs a project agreement with the nucleo ejecutor, and initially disburses about 60 percent of the expected costs to a bank account opened for this purpose. The nucleo ejecutor can then begin to execute the project by hiring the community or a private contractor, NGO, or municipality to do so. In these instances, FONCODES has followed Bank guidelines for procurement of goods and services. 3.42 The nucleo ejecutor must also sign an agreement with an inspector acceptable to FONCODES. This inspector directly oversees project execution, and reports to the FONCODES supervisor on all technical, administrative and accounting issues. He or she is paid by the nucleo ejecutor out of the proceeds of the FONCODES grant. Funds in the project bank account are controlled jointly by the inspector and the treasurer of the nucleo ejecutor. 3.43 Project supervision is carried out by the Department of Projects. On-site supervision is done directly by FONCODES regional staff, or is contracted to intermediaries, such as the College of Engineers, with clear terms of reference. Supervisors' responsibilities include: (i) monitoring project execution; (ii) overseeing the work done by the inspector; (iii) authorizing disbursements; (iv) ensuring compliance with contract covenants concerning nucleos ejecutores, contractors, and suppliers; (v) verifying community participation and arrangements for the operation and maintenance and project sustainability; and (vi) signing the project completion report, checking accounts, and setting the final financial balance. 3.44 The Midterm Review confirmed that the execution and supervision of FONCODES projects generally works smoothly; 63 percent of the beneficiaries reported that there had been "no problems" in the execution of projects. Beneficiary assessments of the work done by nucleos ejecutores, inspectors, and FONCODES supervisors have also been positive; 68 percent of beneficiaries regarded the nucleos ejecutores as democratically elected bodies made up of community members; 61 percent of beneficiaries personally knew the project inspector, who was said to have visited the project site at least once every two weeks in 63 percent of the cases; 54 percent of beneficiaries reported that FONCODES supervisors had made suggestions that contributed to "a better execution of 40
 the project". Only 8 percent said that they had made no suggestions, or that these had not been valuable. The most serious shortcoming of the project execution cycle appears to be the frequent delays with the second disbursement of funds; 14 percent of beneficiaries indicated that there had been "problems" as a result of such delays or a shortage in construction materials, and 42 percent of FONCODES projects were completed behind schedule. FONCODES is currently working with supervisors, who authorize the second disbursement of funds on the basis of project progress or completion, to address this bottleneck in the execution process. H. OPERATIONS AND MAITENANCE 3.45 To achieve sustainability, FONCODES has put in place some mechanisms for the operation and maintenance of projects. It has done this by: (i) coordinating with the line ministries or municipalities so that they assume the recurrent costs of completed FONCODES projects. This is the method used with social infrastructure projects (schools, health posts), and some economic infrastructure projects (roads, sewerage and waste disposal, potable water); (ii) organizing and training the beneficiaries in the operation and maintenance of projects. This is the method used with some economic infrastructure projects (small irrigation schemes, land rehabilitation); and (iii) cost recovery, by charging user fees. This is the method used with some economic infrastructure projects (secondary rural electrification, sewerage and waste disposal, potable water), and some social assistance projects (packages of basic medicines). 3.46 The Midterm Review indicated that sustainability continued to be an area of concern for some projects financed by FONCODES. Most beneficiaries (58 percent) were aware that they had agreed to be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the project in question, and the level of beneficiary participation in the operation and maintenance of FONCODES projects was reasonably high; 52 percent of beneficiaries had contributed, in most cases with their labor (84 percent), money (16 percent), or materials (8 percent). Only a third of beneficiaries, however, had received training in operation and maintenance of the project in question (40 percent for small irrigation schemes). The Midterm Review also indicated that beneficiaries appeared to be willing to pay for better services, especially in the areas of potable water (75 percent), electricity (72 percent), and health (66 percent). 3.47 The project would improve mechanisms for the operation and maintenance of FONCODES projects by: (i) improving coordination between FONCODES, the line ministries, and the municipalities (see Section I); (ii) making training in operation and maintenance mandatory in the execution of some subprojects (irrigation schemes, productive projects) and including the cost of training in the project budget; (iii) encouraging FONCODES to contract specialists in community organization to liaise with community groups, local governments and NGOs to assist communities in the preparation of sustainable projects; (iv) organizing communities on a more permanent basis through the articulated development projects and other pilot projects; (v) including cost recovery as one of the items to be discussed between FONCODES and counterparts in the areas of 41
 health, potable water, and electrification; and (vi) ensuring that FONCODES promoters discuss the recurrent costs associated with various types of projects with communities during the process of prioritization and selection. The adequacy of mechanisms to ensure the operation and maintenance of subprojects will be a performance indicator for the project which will be reviewed during Bank supervision missions and annual reviews. I. COORDINATION WITH LINE MINISTRIES AND MUNICIPALITIES 3.48 Coordination between FONCODES, the line ministries and municipalities is indispensable and mutually beneficial for several reasons: FONCODES often finances projects which are complementary or parallel to those of other government agencies; FONCODES has the capacity to work with communities in remote areas which may be beyond the reach of the line ministries; local governments in rural areas are often weak and can benefit from the experience gained in working with FONCODES on the identification, preparation and implementation of small scale investment projects; FONCODES resources can be stretched further if they are combined with the Municipal Compensation Funds available to local governments. To promote smooth coordination, FONCODES has signed formal agreements, convenios,with the ministries of the Presidency (UTE- FONAVI), Health, Education (lNFES), Agriculture, Energy and Mines, Interior, and Transportation, with INEI and the Superintendencia of Aduanas at the national level, and with other agencies, such as local power authorities, at the regional or local level. These agreements stipulate that FONCODES will not, for example, initiate the construction of a school or health post unless the line ministry in question agrees to staff it and meet all additional recurrent costs in terms of personnel, supplies and maintenance. All project proposals presented to FONCODES must include an approval letter from the line ministry or agency in question. These are discussed and cleared with the relevant ministry in Lima. 3.49 Formal agreements between FONCODES, the line ministries and local authorities generally appear to be working well. The Midterm Review indicated that only 4 percent of completed FONCODES projects are not in use within a year after completion, and in only 10 percent of these cases because the relevant line ministry has not provided the required staff. The Midterm Review did suggest, however, that 21 percent of beneficiaries felt that "additional financing for equipment" was necessary in order for FONCODES projects to "operate adequately". 3.50 To address these and other concerns, FONCODES will create a working group which will meet regularly with counterparts from the ministries of Education, Health, Agriculture, and Transportation. This working group will be charged with ensuring that the agreements signed between FONCODES and the line ministries are properly implemented. In addition, FONCODES will include equipment in the budgets of some social infrastructure projects (construction and rehabilitation of classrooms), and conduct a comprehensive nation-wide survey through the regional offices to determine the proportion of FONCODES projects which are inadequately staffed. FONCODES is currently reviewing the guidelines for secondary electrification projects to ensure that they meet the technical criteria established by local electrification authorities. 42
 3.51 In the future, FONCODES intends to target a greater share of its resources at rural communities in the Sierra and Selva, where the most abject poverty in Peru is found. FONCODES and PRONAMACHCS, an agency of the Ministry of Agriculture which works on small irrigation schemes, soil conservation, and reforestation projects in these rural communities, have signed an agreement to coordinate their activities. This agreement will standardize poverty criteria, coordinate work by geographic area, and establish incentives which would encourage FONCODES and PRONAMACHCS to work on rural projects which reinforce each other. FONCODES and PRONAMACHCS have not yet been able to reach agreement on their approach to the contribution of beneficiaries in support of projects, and are continuing to work together to resolve this issue. 3.52 To date, municipal governments have been involved officially in the preparation and execution of about 10 percent of FONCODES projects. Although more may have been involved informally, there is no documentation of their involvement. The project will encourage further cooperation between FONCODES and local governments by building on the recommendations of an ongoing study conducted by the Plan de Estabilizaci6n Social (PES). This study, "Participation of Local Governments in the Implementation of FONCODES Productive Projects", identifies ways in which local governments can assist communities to prioritize their needs, prepare project proposals, co-finance FONCODES projects using the Municipal Compensation Fund, and participate in their operation and maintenance. Cooperation between FONCODES and municipal governments is expected to increase as a program to train employees of local and regional governments, the Program for Decentralization and Municipal Training, administered by the Ministry of the Presidency, builds capacity at the municipal level. In addition, the training activities financed by the project will include training for representatives of local governments in the preparation of projects which are eligible for FONCODES support. 3.53 Two additional studies financed by the PES, "Re-assessment of the Institutional and Operational Strategy of FONCODES", and "Strategic Planning for FONCODES", propose a strategy for a future transfer of responsibilities for some social infrastructure and social assistance projects from FONCODES to other government bodies, such as the line ministries and municipalities. A third study, "Articulation Between FONCODES and the Line Sectors in Social Assistance and Infrastructure", reviews coordination between FONCODES and the ministries of Education and Health. These studies outline an overall coordination strategy; explore ways in which the some of the projects requested by poor communities, especially for education and health infrastructure, might be incorporated into the annual plans and budgets of the line ministries and/or the municipalities; and transfer know-how about efficient, low-cost, rapid execution methods from FONCODES to the line ministries and/or municipalities. Many of the recommendations of these studies have been incorporated in the updated Operations Manuals, the strategies for working with line ministries and local governments, and the decentralization plan. 3.54 The project will provide for ongoing evaluation of the coordination between FONCODES, the line ministries, and municipal governments. Progress will be measured 43

These indicators will include: (i) adequacy of staffing and equipment of FONCODES projects; (ii) average time between project completion and beginning of operation; and (iii) adequacy of the arrangements to ensure operation and maintenance of projects; and (iv) participation levels of municipal governments in the development, co- financing, and operation and maintenance of FONCODES projects. K. PROJECT BENEFITS, RISKS, AND SAFEGUARDS 3.59 Project Benefits: The project would be an integral component of the government's poverty alleviation strategy and finance approximately 9,000 subprojects in low-income areas of the country. Expected benefits include: (i) generation of short- and long-term employment and income in poor areas; (ii) rehabilitation and construction of high-return social and economic infrastructure. A recent survey of basic needs in more than 18,000 poor communities indicated that only 32% had safe water and waste disposal systems, 13% had electricity, and 90% had a primary school. The project is expected to satisfy virtually 100% of the need for primary education infrastructure, about 50% of the need for water and sewerage systems, and approximately 20 % of the need for electricity; (iii) improvements in the availability and accessibility of social services; (iv) strengthening of local capacity to identify problems, establish priorities for community investments, design, and execute small-scale projects; (v) promotion of community participation and grass-roots democratic processes which help strengthen the fabric of civil society; (vi) creation and reinforcement of links between informal community groups, local governments and the line ministries, thus contributing to the formulation of a realistic national strategy for decentralization of public administration functions; (vii) additional investments in poor areas by central and local governments and the private sector which result from the construction by FONCODES of economic infrastructure; (viii) development of productive activities in low-income areas; (ix) enhanced capacity on the 45
 part of FONCODES to target, appraise and monitor investments oriented to alleviate poverty, and transfer of these skills to other organizations in the public sector. 3.60 The project would give particular attention to extremely poor communities in rural areas, indigenous groups, and women. To minimiize the risk of a deterioration in the quality of FONCODES work, assurances would be sought that the experience and qualifications of FONCODES managers continue to be acceptable to the Bank and that the Bank would be notified promptly of changes in the management staff. In addition, changes in the User's Guide or the Operational Manual would require prior Bank approval. Productive projects, which are expected to receive a larger share of FONCODES resources in the future, will be subject to disbursement limitations, specific guidelines related to their identification, preparation and implementation, and a series of ex-ante and ex-post evaluations to ensure their viability and appropriateness as part of the FONCODES project portfolio. Arrangements for project operations and maintenance, including community-based training, will be an integral part of the project design in the future; revised agreements with the line ministries and municipalities together with regular monitoring of coordination between the community-based nucleos ejecutores, the local governments and the line ministries are expected to contribute to greater project sustainability.  Annex 11 Lessons Learned from Bank Involvement in Social Funds 1. The Bank's experience with more than 30 social investment fands (SIFs) in 24 countries is extensive and continues to grow. Lessons learned can be grouped in three broad categories: (i) staffing and procedures; (ii) the sub-project cycle, including targeting mechanisms and beneficiary participation; and (iii) cooperation with other actors in the public, not-for-profit, and private sectors. 2. Staffing and procedures: Innovative procedures for staffing and operations have allowed social funds to function with a high degree of efficiency and transparency. The most successful social funds have: (i) a high degree of autonomy, which has protected funds from interference in the project selection and approval process by political and other interest groups, given them credibility, and made them less dependent on the vagaries of the annual budget cycle and its cumbersome mechanisms for the transfer of central government funds to line ministries and municipalities; (ii) a cadre of highly qualified professional managerial staff, who are often recruited from the private sector, have a non-bureaucratic work ethic, and are paid salaries competitive with those of the private sector; (iii) exemption from government procurement and disbursement procedures; this has enabled funds to award contracts to private consultants and construction firms using simplified competitive procedures and greatly speeding up the preparation, appraisal, and execution of small investment projects; and (iv) accountability mechanisms which include well-defined project appraisal criteria, transparent procedures, and regular project supervision, operational and financial audits. 2 For comprehensive accounts of lessons learned see especially Phillip J. Glaessner, Kye Woo Lee, Anna Maria Sant'Anna, Jean-Jacques de St. Antoine, Poverty Alleviation and Social Investment Funds: The Latin American Experience, 1994; Mary Schmidt and Alexandre Marc, Participation in Social Funds, 1995; Alexandre Marc, Carol Graham, Marc Schachter, Mary Schmidt, Social Action Programs and Social Funds: A Review of Design and Implementation in Sub-Saharan Africa, 1995; Lynn S. Khadiagala, Social Funds: Strengths, Weaknesses, and Conditions for Success, 1995; and Soniya Carvalho, Social Funds: Guidelines for Design and Implementation, 1994. 64
 3. The sub-project cycle: Social investment funds have generally been demand-driven institutions which have operated as financial intermediaries rather than as implementers. The sub- project cycles of successful funds have some or all of the following characteristics: (i) extra support in project identification, preparation, and community organization for the poorest isolated rural communities, especially indigenous peoples; (ii) targeting mechanisms which ensure that the poor are the principal beneficiaries. For this purpose, funds have generally used a combination of geographic targeting based on poverty maps constructed from a number of indicators of shortages of basic social services, means-testing, self- targeting, and beneficiary assessments; (iii) strong local participation of beneficiaries in all aspects of sub-project selection, preparation, execution and maintenance. High levels of beneficiary participation generally improve outcomes by ensuring that the sub-project is relevant to beneficiary needs, and generate commitment to sustaining project activities and benefits. Beneficiary participation is also valuable because communities which are given the responsibility and capacity to identify, implement, and supervise sub-projects are generally better prepared to involve themselves in future development activities; and (iv) adequate provisions for operations and maintenance after project completion. 4. Coordination with other actors: Social investment funds are vehicles for the alleviation of hardship caused by economic crisis and structural adjustment policies and, more recently, instruments for the long-term reduction of poverty. Coordination between social funds and other actors, especially line ministries and municipalities, is therefore indispensable to avoid duplication of efforts, ensure the sustainability of projects, and transfer know-how, operating methods, and responsibilities for the construction of small-scale infrastructure and the provision of social services. Successful social funds have: (i) a philosophy which is consistent with the general macroeconomic framework; (ii) a flexible institutional framework which has allowed funds to adapt to changing external circumstances. In some instances, social investment funds have been an important vehicle to promote decentralization by strengthening public sector management at the municipal level. After the passage of the "Ley de Participaci6n Popular" in Bolivia, for example, the FIS changed its operations in accordance with the new strategy for decentralization and worked much more closely with municipalities; 65
 (iii) effective working agreements between the social fund and concerned line ministries to promote the integration of national and regional plans with locally generated investments; and (iv) willingness to engage in partnerships with local authorities, the private sector and NGOs, all of whom can be successful at mobilizing resources at the local level, delivering basic services at low cost, and finding innovative solutions to development problems. 66

doc.abstracts: The Second Social Development and Compensation Fund Project for Peru will continue to support the Government's poverty alleviation strategy and will contribute to the government's decentralization strategy by building local capacity in project planning, execution, operations and maintenance of small scale infrastructure and public services. It will also contribute to the longer term goal of sustained poverty reduction through investments in productive projects designed to stimulate economic activity in poor communities. The project components are: (1) community-based subprojects in social infrastructure, social assistance, economic infrastructure and productive activities; and (2) institutional development.
